name: Texas Muslim Womens Foundation Inc
mission: Founded in 2005, Texas Muslim Women's Foundation (TMWF) aims to empower, promote and support all women and their families, with a special focus on North Texas. We are an equal opportunity provider. We engage all members of the community – women, men, seniors, families and youth through our various programs. We provide social and family violence services that foster peace and well-being in the home through our Peace in the Home Services and Peaceful Oasis Shelter. In addition, TMWF also arranges leadership skills development for Muslim youth to inspire the next generation to build a promising future for our society and educational programs for Muslim and non-Muslim community members to learn about topics essential to individual and community welfare.
theoryOfChange: The Texas Muslim Women's Foundation (TMWF) has a published report titled "From the Roots of Trauma to the Flowering of Trauma-Informed Care". This report details TMWF's four-year project to design and implement culturally-sensitive trauma-informed programming for domestic violence survivors and their children. It outlines their process of becoming a trauma-informed agency, which included learning about types of trauma and trauma-informed care, assessing existing culturally-sensitive practices, identifying new practices, training staff, and collaborating with researchers to document and build a body of evidence-based practice, all while maintaining a survivor-centered approach. The report articulates a model that integrates culturally-sensitive services and trauma-informed advocacy, which TMWF invites others to learn from and replicate.
zakatClaimEvidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://www.tmwf.org/ways-to-give (Source: https://www.tmwf.org/ways-to-give)

judge_issues.message: The rationale mentions strong financial efficiency and high alignment for Muslim donors, but doesn't explicitly mention the significant risk deduction due to the small board size. This is a key factor that significantly lowered the overall score and should be included in the rationale.

The impact rationale mentions the need for more comprehensive cost-per-beneficiary data, which is accurate. However, it could also mention the weak governance (small board) and lack of evidence/outcomes data, which also contributed to the lower impact score.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization demonstrates strong financial efficiency and high alignment for Muslim donors, though its overall score is moderated by a medium impact rating and limited working capital.
areas_for_improvement: Limited working capital of 3.7 months, which may impact long-term financial resilience.
Opportunity to increase data transparency to improve the medium data confidence rating.

dimension_explanations.alignment: With a high donor fit and a focus on the urgent cause of domestic poverty and safety, the organization scores a 35/50 in alignment [1]. Its status as a zakat-eligible institution further strengthens its connection to the specific philanthropic needs of the Muslim community [2][8].
dimension_explanations.impact: The foundation focuses on direct provision of services, including emergency shelter and transitional housing for domestic violence survivors [4][6]. While it maintains a high program expense ratio of 86.0%, the impact score of 24/50 reflects a balanced view of its direct service model and the need for more comprehensive cost-per-beneficiary data [1][3].

baseline_narrative.headline: Texas Muslim Women's Foundation empowers survivors of domestic violence and promotes community well-being through culturally sensitive social services and education.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 86.0%, ensuring the vast majority of funds directly support services.
Exceptional fundraising efficiency with a cost of only $0.03 per $1 raised.
Strong financial health and accountability as reflected by a Charity Navigator score of 98.66666666666667/100.
baseline_narrative.summary: Texas Muslim Women's Foundation Inc provides essential social services, youth leadership development, and educational programs designed to improve well-being within and beyond the Muslim community [1][3]. The organization operates as a zakat-eligible entity, allowing donors to fulfill religious obligations through contributions to its various support programs [2][8].

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to support Muslim survivors of domestic violence through a highly efficient, zakat-eligible local institution in North Texas.
donor_motivations: Want to fulfill zakat obligations through domestic social services
Value culturally sensitive crisis intervention for Muslim women
Prioritize low overhead and high fundraising efficiency
giving_considerations: Donations support direct shelter and housing costs
The organization is a mature institution with a 20+ year history
Focus is regional (North Texas) rather than national or international
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking international humanitarian relief or those who require rigorous academic RCT evidence of impact.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects consistent internal tracking of beneficiaries and outputs, but a lack of independent external evaluation.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: TMWF provides a continuum of care from emergency shelter to transitional housing and social services to break the cycle of violence.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that shelter and housing programs effectively lead to long-term survivor independence.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With a high funding gap and growing demand for housing, TMWF can effectively absorb additional capital for service expansion.

strengths.detail: The organization demonstrates remarkable fiscal discipline, spending just <cite id="8">$0.03 per $1 raised</cite>, which is significantly better than industry benchmarks.
TMWF holds a <cite id="12">perfect 100 score for Culture and Leadership</cite> from Charity Navigator, alongside <cite id="13">100% independent board members</cite>.

The foundation successfully housed <cite id="14">137 emergency shelter residents</cite> and supported <cite id="15">216 non-residential domestic violence clients</cite> in its most recent reporting period.

strengths_deep_dive: The Texas Muslim Women's Foundation excels in operational transparency and financial management, as evidenced by its <cite id="4">98.66666666666667/100 rating</cite> from Charity Navigator. Its financial resilience is supported by <cite id="16">3.7 months of working capital</cite>, ensuring stability for its critical crisis services. The foundation's growth is notable, achieving a <cite id="17">3-year revenue CAGR of 17.3%</cite>, which allows for the expansion of its <cite id="18">transitional and permanent housing programs</cite> that served 149 survivors in previous cycles.
rich_narrative.summary: The Texas Muslim Women's Foundation (TMWF) is a specialized social service agency that <cite id="1">empowers survivors of domestic violence</cite> through culturally sensitive advocacy and shelter. Founded in <cite id="2">2005</cite>, the organization has evolved into a comprehensive provider of <cite id="3">emergency shelter, transitional housing, and senior programs</cite> across North Texas. TMWF maintains a <cite id="4">98.66666666666667/100 overall score from Charity Navigator</cite>, reflecting a high standard of accountability and financial health. In the 2023 fiscal year, the foundation reported <cite id="5">total revenue of $4,665,216</cite>, driven largely by <cite id="6">$4,618,531 in public contributions</cite>. The organization operates with high efficiency, maintaining a <cite id="7">program expense ratio of 86.0%</cite> while spending only <cite id="8">$0.03 to raise every $1</cite> in funding. Beyond crisis intervention, TMWF provides <cite id="9">social services and youth leadership development</cite> to promote long-term community well-being. Their impact is quantifiable, having provided <cite id="10">emergency shelter to 186 survivors</cite> and assisted <cite id="11">204 individuals with transitional or rapid re-housing</cite> in 2023 alone.
